conclusion: The light source moves to the front right, away from the objects, affecting the position and size of shadows A, B, C, and D.
Shadows slide in the direction opposite to the displacement of the lamp, moving toward the back-left part of the floor.
The lamp being farther away causes rays to become more parallel, resulting in longer ground projections for taller objects and reduced lateral enlargement due to perspective.
Object A is the ballerina’s head/upper body.
The shadow of object A shifts back-left, no longer lying inside the white skirt’s shadow.
The vertical height of object A above the floor causes its shadow’s back-left plume to grow longer.
Object B is the vertical brown leaf/feather.
The tiny blob shadow of object B moves back-left.
Being tall and thin, object B’s shadow becomes an elongated, back-left-pointing streak instead of a small patch.
Object C is the white skirt/disc.
The round skirt shadow of object C slides back-left, exposing new floor where it used to be.
The skirt’s lower rim being near the ground causes its shadow outline to hardly lengthen, with only folds casting slightly longer tongues on the back-left edge.
Object D is the low paper airplane.
The shallow wedge-shaped shadow of object D slips slightly to the back-left.
Object D being almost flush with the floor causes its shadow’s footprint to change very little, with only a slight sideways stretch on the left edge.
All four shadows migrate to the rear-left quadrant of the picture.
Tall items (A and B) show the greatest increase in shadow length, medium-height surfaces (C’s rim) show modest changes, and near-ground items (D) change mainly in position, not size.
Final conclusion: Shadows A, B, C, and D change in position and size as described when the light source moves to the front right and farther away.
